name: Preservation of the Xinhai Revolution
description: Ironically, Fengtian is the sole national government upholding the order established by the Xinhai Revolution in 1911, which called for the overthrow of the Qing and the establishment of a Republic. Although its republican commitments are questionable, and Southern reclamation is currently unrealistic, the government has loudly advocated both goals, as they foster domestic legitimacy.

name: Suppress Regionalist Sentiment
description: For many years, Zhang Zuolin's primary political slogan was 'The Northeast for the Northeast', but when his ambitions turned toward Beijing, this regionalist message had to be set aside. Ever since, it has proven a thorn in the Grand Marshal's side, and many still espouse these old sentiments. The time has come to put the matter to rest once and for all.

name: Silence Targeted Subversives
description: The regionalist movement has never been organized, but it has received support from the local gentry, school teachers, and government bureaucrats. Some of these figures have become increasingly prominent, and by silencing them we may cut the head from the regionalist snake. Some can be bribed, and others can be threatened or fired - to say nothing of other persusaive methods.

name: Justify Mass Arrests
description: So long as the regionalist movement remains peaceful, we lack the institutional and public support to crush it decisively. By dispatching agents disguised as protestors we can push the movement toward violent means, cost them their public support, and then justify mass arrests.

name: Fuguo Qiangbing
description: Translating roughly to 'Enrich the Country, Strengthen the Army', this proverb dates back to ancient legalist philosophers, but has been used more recently to inspire reforms in both Guangxu Era China and Meiji Era Japan. Now it is applied again in Fengtian, as the government seeks to modernise and eventually strike South against the resurgent Zhili Clique, and from there establish control over all China.

name: Open the Propaganda Front
description: Sometimes the most decisive battles are fought and won in hearts and minds. We have fought a passive war of words with [QIE.GetNameDef] ever since 1928, and now the time has come to begin a new offensive and redouble our efforts. Ten thousand years to the Republic!

name: Develop the Three Northeast Provinces
description: The Three Northeast Provinces, Fengtian, Jilin, and Heilongjiang, already contain over 30% of China's railroads and much of its heavy industry. However, if the National Reclamation War is to be won, both will have to be expanded upon and improved. Ideally this would be achieved solely by the Chinese people, but reality dictates that the Japanese will lead much of the path forward.

name: Wang Yongjiang's Legacy
description: Manchuria's transformation from a backward borderland into one of China's most prosperous regions owes itself to the work of Wang Yongjiang, Zhang Zuolin's late Finance Minister. Disgusted by the Grand Marshal's costly excursions south of the Great Wall in 1928, Wang resigned and died shortly thereafter, his work left unfinished. We must pick up where he left off.

name: Yamato Hotel Licences
description: One of Mantetsu's most successful ventures in Manchuria is its Yamato Hotel franchise, which serves the countless Japanese businessmen who make their way to and from the Home Islands every day. Despite the unwelcome influence they bear, their skills and capital are crucial. We must decide their future.

name: Mantetsu Research Wing
description: Mantetsu's Research Wing, known as 'Mantetsu Chōsabu', serves as the centrepiece of Japan's colonial programme, and pursues a wide variety of scientific goals. Its massive funding and talent pool could be of great use to us in our own efforts.

name: Mantetsu Collaboration
description: Mantetsu, also known as the 'South Manchuria Railway Company', exerts an enormous amount of control over our economy, with numerous subsidiaries ranging from flour mills to hospitals. Its aid will unfortunately be essential to developing most aspects of our economy that require Japanese technical expertise.

name: Japanese Electrical Expertise
description: Thanks to China's backwardness over the past century, and the chaos of the past two decades, the country has few native engineers. Japanese assistance will be essential in bringing modernity to the Northeast.

name: Found the Northeast IDC
description: At Japanese recommendation, a proposal has been put forth to organise several influential businessmen and politicians into a body called the 'Northeastern Industrial Development Commission' that might guide Fengtian's industrial development.

name: Expand the Anshan Mines
description: The enormous iron deposits in Anshan have been described as being of 'world class significance', and churn out nearly 7 million tonnes of iron, with the potential to triple output by 1942. This expansion seems likely to propel Anshan toward becoming one of East Asia's largest industrial centres.

name: Reorganise the NTC
description: Founded by the Fengtian Government shortly after its creation, the National Transportation Commission serves as a planning board for infrastructure construction across the country. The Japanese allege that its foremost aim is to disrupt Mantetsu's operations, and there may be at least some truth to this claim.

name: Develop the Northern Frontier
description: The northern reaches of Heilongjiang and Xing'an have been dominated by mountainous boreal forests since time immemorial, swept by bitter Siberian winds and inhabited only by passing nomads. Modern technologies could allow settlers to penetrate this hostile environment and pursue rumors of coal, gold, and graphite in the Khingan Mountains.

name: Fengtian Society for Light Metals
description: Significant deposits of Bauxite and Alunite have been known to exist in Fengtian Province for many years, but recent advances by Mantetsu sponsored laboratories in Fushun and Tokyo have enabled Aluminium production via a number of electro-chemical processes.

name: Mantetsu Civil Engineering Projects
description: While the Japanese have much to benefit directly from large civil engineering projects in Fengtian, they also do so indirectly by helping to present our regime as successful at improving the everyday lives of citizens. In this respect, our interests are mutually aligned.

name: Establish the Jinzhou Industrial Zone
description: Jinzhou's docks and strategic position in the 'Liaoxi Corridor', which connects land transportation between North and Northeast China, make it a prime target for government incentivised development. It remains to be seen whether special rules will be applied to this zone favouring Chinese or Japanese companies.

name: Expand the Fushun Mines
description: The mines around Fushun churn out nearly 11 million tons of coal per year, with deposits promising to produce over 4.5 billion tonnes total. While some modern trains and ships in the West use oil, the Japanese Empire runs on coal, and the strategic significance of these mines cannot be understated.

name: Yalu and Songhua Hydroelectricity
description: Manchuria's abundant coal deposits make for an excellent power source, but the strong currents of the Yalu and Songhua rivers could provide additional power at minimal expense. With Japanese expertise, we might harness these mighty rivers to power more homes and industry.

name: Yingkou Commercial Development
description: The port city of Yingkou serves as Fengtian's primary gateway to the world, and the second largest port on the Bohai Gulf after Japanese-controlled [GetDalianName]. The tremendous increase in material production in Fengtian demands an equally large investment in commercial infrastructure.

name: Support Sino-Japanese Joint Companies
description: A great number of businesses in Fengtian offer shares to both Chinese and Japanese, including the infamous Mantetsu, but relatively few Chinese have the funds to invest and as a result most joint companies are Japanese dominated. Government backing may permit us to provide means and incentives to fellow Chinese and gradually shift this balance.

name: Japanese Coal Gasification Methods
description: Japan's quest for crucial oil lead it to Manchuria, but now with disappointing results from prospecting, coal gasification seems the only logical path forward. Though energy intensive, Fushun's enormous coal deposits could make the complex processes worthwhile.

name: Manchurian Model Cities
description: Japan sometimes goes to surprising lengths to portray its role in Fengtian as one of benevolent paternalism, to which end Mantetsu plans to install state of the art electrical, sewer, and tram systems in the major cities of Shenyang, Changchun, and Harbin.

name: From Beijing to the Begonia Leaf
description: For decades, students and nationalists have compared the shape of China, that is to say China undivided, to the shape of a Begonia leaf. With Beijing in our hands, it has come time to reclaim all of our homeland, and make the Begonia Leaf a reality!

name: Unification by Negotiation
description: Since 1911, all attempts to truly unify China by way of negotiation have met with failure, as divides have proven insurmountable. However, after so many years of conflict and division, with Beijing now unquestionably in the Grand Marshal’s hands, it may be possible to bring at least some of China’s parties and factions to the negotiating table.

name: Restore the 1923 Constitution
description: The 1923 Constitution was widely recognized as China’s most modern, but the sheer corruption of Cao Kun’s Zhili Clique made its proclamation ring hollow, and its implementation impossible. Since 1928, when Fengtian was passed the torch of Republicanism, the Constitution has remained suspended due to strategic necessity. The time has come to restore the old constitution and resume elections.

name: Limited Women's Suffrage
description: Universal suffrage is a step too far, as gender roles are at the very foundation of any morally upright confucian society, but Song Qingling has demanded at least limited suffrage for women. With the right preparations made, women across the country will soon be able to vote in local elections, in spite of the move’s questionable popularity.

name: The China Welfare Fund
description: Song Qingling, wife to the late Dr. Sun, is a figure around whom all Republicans can rally. In return for her political support, Mrs. Song has asked that [FNG.GetNameDef] make several guarantees in return. The first of these is the creation of the China Welfare Fund, which will funnel government aid toward women and children; often those at greatest risk of hunger and destitution.

name: Toward the Third Principle
description: “Minsheng” or “People’s Welfare” is the last of Dr. Sun Yat-Sen’s three principles, but no less important than its fellows. Through various educational and developmental programs Song Qingling hopes to eventually realize this principle. The Fengtian Government will allocate a number of resources to this end.

name: Revived Rural Reconstruction
description: The rural hinterland of China has been neglected for far too long. It is time to formulate a comprehensive plan to revive development in these areas in order to join them to the richer, coastal areas and bridge the urban-rural divide. Nationally organised public works programs, including the construction of additional canals and railways, should give a boost to this development.

name: Redefine Provincial Obligations
description: One of the promises made to Chen Jiongming by Zhang Zuolin was assurances that the new government would adopt federalist characteristics. The provinces will be allowed to levy their own independent taxes, though they must be subject to Central Government oversight. It's not a satisfying compromise to both sides, but so are compromises.

name: Building the Road to Federalism
description: Another promise made to Chen Jiongming was to approve the creation of democratically elected provincial assemblies, organized according to provincial constitutions. The Central Government will now make allowances for these activities, but it reserves the right to appoint governors, each of whom wields the power to veto any distasteful decisions made by these provincial assemblies.

name: Twin Dragons Taming the Water
description: After decades of chaos, disunity, and poor governance, a watchful peace under the bipartite rule of Grand Marshal Zhang Zuolin and Prime Minister Chen Jiongming seems like paradise indeed. Together they have become known as “Twin Dragons Taming the Water”, though some question whether this harmony can last forever.

name: Suppress the Bandits; Collect the Harvest
description: The last time soldiers of the Fengtian Army entered the North China Plain, some units were encouraged to suppress banditry and assist in collection the seasonal harvest in return for lodgings and food. Where such amenities were normally simply seized, these tactics seem to have ameliorated local unrest and partisan activity. All commanders would do well to follow this example.

name: Continue the Reclamation War
description: The war of National Reclamation did not end with the capture of Beijing. One by one, each of China’s provinces must be brought to heel, and the country once again unified.

name: Integrate Occupied Arsenals
description: The Shenyang Arsenal is unquestionably the greatest in China, but by integrating and specializing newly seized arsenals, now as part of a national supply system, we may be able to ease the burden on Shenyang and improve our overall logistical capability.

name: Crush Flies and Capture Pigs
description: Corruption and abuse of power have run rampant throughout China over the past several decades, and all levels of the Fengtian Government are complicit in this activity. In order to regain the public’s trust, some measure of law and order must be restored, and examples will be made of both low-level “Flies” and high-level “Pigs”, who have been greedily gorging themselves on the nation’s livelihood.

name: Expand the Baojia System
description: The Baojia System is an ancient method of social organization and military recruitment. Zhang Zuolin revived the practice several decades ago in the Northeast, and to great effect, but now the time has come to once again expand the system to the rest of China, where it has by and large fallen by the wayside.

name: Incorporate Local Patronage Networks
description: There is more to every institution than meets the eye, and every good warlord builds his stronghold through a network of reciprocal partnerships negotiated behind closed doors. With the collapse of enemy authority, there are many such individuals and institutions without a clear place in the new order. There is every reason to begin incorporating these individuals into our own networks, where possible.

name: Broaden the Bingzhan Network
description: The Fengtian Army has long been renowned for its outstanding system of logistics, allowing its soldiers to receive regular rations and ammunition where others are forced to forage or steal from peasants. A key component in the system are “Bingzhan” or logistics depots, which must now be built in recently conquered areas.

name: Reclaim the Railways
description: Mostly built by Western hands, or at the very least funded by foreign capital, China’s railways have always been seen as a symbol of imperialism. Many are still owned in part by the same American or European corporations which built them, and the time has come to formally reclaim these railways and solidify the Central Government’s control over its own rail network, no matter the cost.

name: Centralize Provincial Revenues
description: Perhaps the greatest source of disunity in China has been the decentralisation of the tax system, begun with the introduction of provincial “Lijin” transit tariffs in 1853. The new Central Government must limit provincial taxation, and reduce the percentage local authorities may keep for themselves. Otherwise, local governments will continue to deny the nation revenue.

name: Institute Labour Discipline
description: The industrial policy of our nation is being threatened by the increasingly divergent interests of industrialists, union leaders and workers. Unions serve only to divide, and creating distrust, forcing the leaders of our country to compromise. Only through a intervention that solidifies the discipline and loyalty of labor organisations, can the unity be forged that will allow us to move our country forward.

name: The Generals Know Best
description: There is no doubt that a centralized army can serve as the foundation to a centralized state, but China's great size requires a different approach. For this reason, we will continue to appoint military governors. To better balance this arrangement, provincial armies must recruit the majority of troops from outside their own provinces, and limit their production and deployment of heavy weapons.

name: One Army One Republic
description: If we are to learn a single lesson from over two thousand years of Chinese history, it is that when military force is divided, so too is the country. In order to build a unified China we must create a single army, beneath a single banner, at the direction of a single command structure. This measure will not be popular at any level of government outside the Cabinet.

name: The Ultimatum
description: China has been crushed and humiliated beneath the bootheel of foreign powers for nearly a century. The time has come for national humiliation to end, and Japan must meet our terms or meet our steel.

name: Unification by Subjugation
description: Negotiations have failed, as they always do, and now there is no choice but to unify China by the sword. Our few friends and allies will now rally behind us as we carry forth the Five Color flag, raising aloft a symbol that unites the hopes and dreams of all Chinese. It was force which broke China, then force which humiliated it, and now force shall make it whole again. The time has come to reclaim our country once and for all!

name: Secure the Rear Areas
description: The North China Plain has been seized, but it has not been pacified. For now, the Army controls only the railways and their immediate proximity, with bandits and partisans running wild beyond. China is a big country, and the rear areas must be thoroughly scoured in order to ensure an uncompromised advance toward the goal of national reunification.

name: The Question of the Presidency
description: In Beijing, they say that when Zuolin stamps his foot the whole city shakes. Yet he is a soldier before a politician, and once no more than a bandit, making many question his suitability for the nation’s highest political office. With gossip already circulating about his advanced age, illiteracy, and vulgarity, his western-tutored son Zhang Xueliang may make a better choice, while Zuolin leads from the shadows.

name: Eliminate Internal Dissent
description: For many years the Fengtian Government has tolerated some measure of political plurality, with a variety of interest groups lobbying the government in return for promises and favors. With Beijing in hand this system must come to an end. Subversive internal elements will be eliminated, and those that remain must toe the government line. There is no other way to govern a Chinese society.

name: Minde Zhuyi
description: Sun Yat-sen was right to call for the three principles. Yet, without morality, how could the people truly devote themselves to the nation? There must be a fourth principle, “People’s Morality”, based on Confucian principles in order to drag China away from the clutches of crime, and vice. Chief among these principles, of course, is appropriate deference to figures of paternal authority.

name: A Father to the People
description: While he may not be suited to the Presidency, the people must be taught to recognize the key role of Zhang Zuolin in our great strides towards unification, and toward an end to a century of national humiliation. In his rise from rags to leader, he has carried with him the aspirations of the people. Ten thousand years to Grand Marshal Zhang Zuolin! Ten thousand years to the Republic of China!

name: Toward Japan
description: The time has come to reach out to our Japanese allies in the name of Pan-Asian cooperation. By lowering barriers to trade and accepting Japanese oversight in certain economic sectors, we can make Manchuria a prosperous cornerstone of the East Asian economy!

name: Chunchi-Xiangyi
description: It was once said that China and Japan are “as close as lips and teeth”, and today further integration can only mean further prosperity. Now we can ensure that China reaps all the benefits of Japanese manufacturing. Some call this the gateway to a captive Chinese market, but we have no need for fear-mongering. What the people want is cheap clothing, radios, and cigarettes!

name: Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation
description: In recognizing the indisputably ascendant position of Japan astride the East, we must acknowledge our own role as equal but subordinate partners in pursuit of the Pan-Asian Dream. The time has come to join Japan’s alliance, and commit ourselves to its esteemable goals.

name: Join the Yen Bloc
description: By adopting the Japanese Yen as a reserve currency, and making it required for all foreign expenditures, Japan and China can present a united fiscal front to the world. This will finalize the process of integrating our economy with that of Japan, and forming an East Asian economic bloc independent from and unspoiled by greedy Western bankers from Washington, Ottawa, and Berlin.

name: Found the Shenyang National Academy
description: In the years of economic hardship following the last Zhifeng War, the Military Academy of the Three Eastern Provinces began to stagnate. By refounding the old academy under a new name and updating its curriculum, it can again become a point of pride.

name: Reorganise the Coastal Defence Forces
description: Because the Fengtian Navy has no realistic way of opposing the larger and newer navy fielded by [QIE.GetNameDef], its main purpose is coastal defence. In light of recent troubling inadequacies, such as one ship's crew selling their armament on the black market, extensive reorganisation and reform is necessary.

name: Expand Yingkou Naval Yard
description: Yingkou is the Northeast Region's second largest port, after Japanese-held [GetDalianName], and the home of our Navy. If we are to begin any meaningful naval reconstruction project, expansion of the Yingkou Naval Yard is an essential first step.

name: The Nine Points Strategy
description: The severe asymmetry in strength between the Fengtian and [QIE.GetAdjective] navies means that, in the absence of Japanese support, our entire coast will be at risk of invasion. Japanese strategists have outlined nine positions at which naval landings are most likely, and drafted plans for their defence.

name: Regular River Patrols
description: The Navy possesses number of small patrol boats, occasionally used to police the Yalu and Songhua rivers, but the majority of which are currently rusting away in storage. These might be better used to train our crews and maintain our internal security, if we can find the funding.

name: Re-Forming the Marine Corps
description: A marine corps was created in 1914, called the 'Republic of China Marine Corps,' but this attempt went nowhere. We will revive the China Marine Corps along modern lines, enabling us to better operate in riverine environments like the Huang He and Yangtze. Given the right opportunity, we may even be able to cross the Bohai Sea, and make Wu Peifu's old strategy our own.

name: Commission Japanese Ships
description: There can be no doubt that our own ship-building capabilities pale compared to those of the Imperial Japanese Navy. They will never give us the ships necessary to build a truly modern fleet, but they might sell us enough to make a difference against other Chinese, and any other future threats.

name: Lessons from the Zhifeng Wars
description: The last Zhili-Fengtian War saw the Fengtian Army fighting enemies whose weapons and technology far outclassed their own. Through trials of fire and blood, improvised weapons and unusual methods emerged to suit the new environment, allowing our soldiers to punch above their weight.

name: Moral Indoctrination
description: Japanese training emphasises the importance of the human factor in maintaining a continuous offensive, with the belief that spirit can triumph over steel. This requires serious moral indoctrination.

name: Modernised Curriculum
description: The modern Japanese curriculum, designed to counter Russian aggression on the plains of Manchuria, emphasises morale factors and tenacity of the will, stressing training designed to develop the ability to recognise opportunities for decisive attack; enveloping open enemy flanks, encircling formations, and thus destroying numerically and technologically superior forces.

name: New Model Army
description: Our new officer corps are now well schooled in the most modern Japanese strategies and tactics available. Now all that remains is to begin the process of graduation, deployment, and integration with the regular troops.

name: The Kwantung Protocol
description: In light of the growing friendship between our two nations, the Kwantung Army has petitioned Japan's Army Ministry to increase cooperation. This is set to include the transfer of weapons and technology, as well as training. All we need to do is add our signature to the prepared document, though accepting will play straight into the hands of the Concordia Association.

name: Obtain Japanese Instructors
description: The Japanese field a modern military and industrial sector comparable in strength and discipline with any in the West. Given that the Japanese government is willing to provide instructors free of charge, we should take this opportunity to build a force our enemies will envy.

name: Jigyou Hikaku
description: The Japanese have recommended that our military-industrial enterprises adopt a strategy of comparing business results, or 'Jigyou Hikaku', in which proprietary data on production is disclosed. They will then rank performance and dispatch consultants to improve our industrial methods. This should boost production, though it will give the Japanese plenty of information about our military industry.

name: Zaibatsu Investments
description: By opening our armaments industry to the Zaibatsu we are inevitably inviting increased Japanese influence in Manchuria. However, they can provide more money than we could ever afford to spend, and their manufacturing processes are far more sophisticated than our own.

name: Collaborative Equipment Design
description: By partnering with Japanese manufacturers to create and streamline designs suited to the unique Chinese environment, we can produce superior weapons at a lower cost. This may make us reliant on expensive Japanese-built machinery, but in the long run we will have the tools we need to pacify all of China.

name: Restructure the China Flying Corps
description: Originally organised by the Grand Marshal's son, Zhang Xueliang, the Corps performed well in the last war, losing air superiority only upon the arrival of more modern German-piloted planes. Since then it's expanded, but retains aircraft decades behind Western standards.

name: Shoutai Tactics
description: Enormous advances in aircraft design in recent years have produced planes that fly completely differently than their predecessors, requiring reevaluations of flight manoeuvring and tactics. The Japanese have reorganized their Air Squadrons into three-plane 'Shoutai' units which are designed around the flexibility necessary for dogfighting. These could give us an important edge.

name: Expand the Shenyang Aerodrome
description: One of China's first military aviation centres, the Shenyang Aerodrome requires expansion in-line with our increasing air power.

name: Request Japanese Airframes
description: While we have a strong air force in comparison to most warlords, our air force still lacks behind the [QIE.GetName] air force in size and modernity, as they are supplied with modern German aircraft. We will need to leverage our relationship to Japan in order to be able to have a chance against them.

name: Reverse Engineering Efforts
description: With some Japanese planes in our possession, it seems possible that we might reverse engineer them for our own use, though the success of such efforts cannot be guaranteed.

name: Request Aircraft Blueprints
description: True aircraft design requires well educated and extremely specialised engineers, which we sadly don't have access to. As a result, in order to improve our air force, we must order more from Japan.

name: Rearm the Northeast
description: The Shenyang Arsenal was once China's greatest military-industrial enterprise, but the past decade has seen it eclipsed by the combined production of other Chinese arsenals, such as those at Hanyang, Baoding, and Jiangnan. We must reclaim our place at the top, and in doing so reduce our reliance on Japanese military aid. We can begin by stamping out corruption and increasing production quotas.

name: Expand the Shenyang Arsenal
description: China's largest military-industrial enterprise through the 1920s, the enormous Shenyang Arsenal produces a wide variety of modified small arms and artillery, usually based around designs acquired from overseas. By expanding its operations and introducing newer equipment we can substantially increase its output.

name: Diversify Armament Production
description: The Shenyang Arsenal has always been a massive but totally centralized operation, with one single plant and sub-factories in the Shenyang area accounting for the entirety of the Northeast's armament production. Eventually, size becomes a burden. We must consider diversifying our equipment manufacturing process to include components built at separate plants, or even by private companies.

name: Develop the Dadong Artillery Complex
description: [FNG.GetLeader] has always had an enthusiasm for big guns, and the Mukden Arsenal has always built its artillery at the Shenyang Mortar Factory in Dadong; a northeastern district of Shenyang. By expanding this operation into a totally seperate artillery complex, we can maximize its efficiency.
